description: Originally developed for use in patients with cardiopulmonary disease, but has since been used in a variety of neurological conditions including MS; evaluates the global and integrated responses of all the systems involved during exercise, including the pulmonary and cardiovascular systems, systemic circulation, peripheral circulation, blood, neuromuscular units, and muscle metabolism
A feasible, reliable, valid and responsive test for measuring walking velocity over 10 meters in people with MS.

description: This form contains all of the general core CDEs and has been duplicated across all of the diseases on the NINDS CDE website.

cdes.cdeName: Birth date
cdes.definitionDescription: Date (and time, if applicable and known) the participant/subject was born
cdes.instructions: Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).  Recording date of birth will give the most detailed information required for calculation of age and is recommended as first choice. However, in some studies recording date of birth may elicit discussions on a potential violation of privacy legislation and specifically HIPAA regulations. In these cases, the calculated age should be recorded.
cdes.referrences: ISO 8601 - http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue.htm Management and prognosis of severe traumatic brain injury: Age. J Neurotrauma. 2000;17:573-581.; Mushkudiani NA, Engel DC, Steyerberg EW, et al. Prognostic value of demographic characteristics in traumatic brain injury: results from the IMPACT study. J Neurotrauma. Feb 2007;24(2):259-69. Pediatric-specific reference(s): Anderson V, Catroppa C, Morse S, Haritou F, Rosenfeld J (2005) Functional plasticity or vulnerability after early brain injury. Pediatrics 116:1374-1382
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: caBIG: PER_BIR_DT; SCI CDEs: BIRTHDT

cdes.cdeName: Gender type
cdes.definitionDescription: Self-reported gender of the participant/subject. Gender is the socially constructed identity of sex. Gender is equated with phenotypic sex. Gender may differ from the sex of an individual determined genetically.
cdes.instructions: Choose one. Response is obtained by report of the participant/subject or caretaker.
cdes.referrences: The NIH Guidelines on Inclusion of Women and Minorities as Subjects in Clinical Research: The Office of Management and Budget Directive No. 15 (http://grants.nih.gov/grants/funding/women_min/guidelines_update.htm)
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: caBIG: PRSN_GENDER_TXT_TP; SCI CDEs: GENDER

cdes.cdeName: Ethnicity USA category
cdes.definitionDescription: Category of ethnicity the participant/subject most closely identifies with
cdes.permissibleValue: Hispanic or Latino;Unknown;Not Hispanic or Latino;Not reported;
cdes.permissibleDescription: A person of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race.  The term “Spanish origin” can also be used in addition to “Hispanic or Latino.”;Could not be determined or unsure;A person not meeting the definition for Hispanic or Latino.;Not reported;
cdes.instructions: Choose one.  Response is obtained by report of the participant/subject or caretaker. If more detailed characterizations of ethnicity are collected to enhance data quality and consistency, it is recommended that they be  collapsible  up to the two categories for reportable ethnicity, as needed for reporting to FDA under its guidance. Other regulatory bodies may expect the reporting of ethnicity values which more appropriately reflect the population of their areas (e.g., Japanese ancestry for MHLW reporting to Japan). These may be collected as an extension to the suggested code list.
cdes.referrences: The NIH Guidelines on Inclusion of Women and Minorities as Subjects in Clinical Research: The Office of Management and Budget Directive No. 15 defines the minimum standard of basic racial and ethnic categories. (http://grants.nih.gov/grants/funding/women_min/guidelines_update.htm)  Collection of Race and Ethnicity Data in Clinical Trials (FDA, September 2005 - http://www.fda.gov/RegulatoryInformation/Guidances/ucm126340.htm)
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: ETHN_GRP_CAT_TXT

cdes.cdeName: Race USA category
cdes.definitionDescription: The patient's self declared racial origination, independent of ethnic origination, using OMB approved categories.
cdes.permissibleValue: American Indian or Alaska Native;White;Asian;Unknown;Black or African-American;Not reported;Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander;
cdes.permissibleDescription: A person having origins in any of the original peoples of North and South America (including Central America) , and who maintains tribal affiliation or community attachment.;A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa.;A person having origins in any of the original peoples of the Far East, Southeast Asia, or the Indian subcontinent including, for example, Cambodia, China, India, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, the Philippine Islands, Thailand, and Vietnam.;Could not be determined or unsure;A person having origins in any of the black racial groups of Africa. Terms such as “Haitian” or “Negro” can be used in addition to “Black or African American.”;Not reported;A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Hawaii, Guam, Samoa, or other Pacific Islands.;
cdes.instructions: Choose all that apply.  Response is obtained by report of the participant/subject or caretaker. Collecting information on race may not be allowed in some countries for concerns related to discrimination. In other countries, however, these concerns are considered a reason for recording race in order to guarantee equal access to care. Investigators receiving funding from the US National Institutes of Health (NIH) are required to report the number of subjects enrolled on an annual basis using the racial categories listed.
cdes.referrences: The NIH Guidelines on Inclusion of Women and Minorities as Subjects in Clinical Research: The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Directive No. 15 defines the minimum standard of basic racial and ethnic categories. (http://grants.nih.gov/grants/funding/women_min/guidelines_update.htm)  Collection of Race and Ethnicity Data in Clinical Trials (FDA, September 2005 - http://www.fda.gov/RegulatoryInformation/Guidances/ucm126340.htm)
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: RACE_CAT_TXT

cdes.cdeName: Education year count
cdes.definitionDescription: Number of years of education completed (age 5 and beyond)
cdes.instructions: For years completed, after the age of 5, code the number of years attained (0-30 years), normed to someone moving full time at the usual pace, i.e. a year that was repeated counts as only 1 year and the usual single-year full-time load completed over several years counts as 1 year. Certificate and technical programs do NOT count no matter how specialized.  The number of  years of typical completion of the relevant program is counted. If the subject obtained their education outside the United States, ask about their educational system to estimate the correct coding - Internship, Residency, and Fellowship years are experiential training and do not count.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.permissibleDescription: A person having origins in any of the original peoples of North and South America (including Central America) , and who maintains tribal affiliation or community attachment.;A person having origins in any of the original peoples of the Far East, Southeast Asia, or the Indian subcontinent including, for example, Cambodia, China, India, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, the Philippine Islands, Thailand, and Vietnam.;A person having origins in any of the black racial groups of Africa. Terms such as “Haitian” or “Negro” can be used in addition to “Black or African American.”;A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Hawaii, Guam, Samoa, or other Pacific Islands.;A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa.;Could not be determined or unsure;Not provided or unavailable;
cdes.instructions: Choose all that apply. Response is obtained by report of the participant/subject or caretaker. Collecting information on race may not be allowed in some countries for concerns related to discrimination. In other countries, however, these concerns are considered a reason for recording race in order to guarantee equal access to care. Investigators receiving funding from the US National Institutes of Health (NIH) are required to report the number of subjects enrolled on an annual basis using the racial categories listed.
cdes.referrences: The NIH Guidelines on Inclusion of Women and Minorities as Subjects in Clinical Research: The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Directive No. 15 defines the minimum standard of basic racial and ethnic categories. (http://grants.nih.gov/grants/funding/women_min/guidelines_update.htm)  Collection of Race and Ethnicity Data in Clinical Trials (FDA, September 2005 - http://www.fda.gov/RegulatoryInformation/Guidances/ucm126340.htm)

description: Based on the current International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) guidelines, this CRF Module is recommended to classify seizures for all epilepsy studies.

cdes.cdeName: Seizure classification type
cdes.definitionDescription: The type of seizures present by classification.
cdes.permissibleDescription: Generalized;Focal;Unclassified seizures are considered unidentifiable due to lack of data and do not fit in to the aforementioned categories for Generalized and Focal Seizures;
cdes.instructions: Choose all that apply.  Each seizure type needs to be answered using the permissible values for the  Seizure type or subtype present likelihood type  data element.  It is possible for a participant/subject to have more than one seizure type.
cdes.referrences: EPILEPSY: Berg AT, Berkovic SF, Brodie MJ, Buchhalter J, et al. Revised terminology and concepts for organization of seizures and epilepsies: report of the ILAE Commission on Classification and Terminology, 2005-2009. Epilepsia. 2010 Apr;51(4):676-85. http://www.ilae-epilepsy.org/Visitors/Centre/ctf/ctfoverview.cfm
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Seizure generalized classification type
cdes.definitionDescription: The type of generalized epileptic seizures, considered to originate at some point within, and rapidly engage, bilaterally distributed networks and may include such bilateral networks as ortical and subcortical structures, but do not necessarily include the entire cortex, experienced by the participant/subject.
cdes.permissibleValue: Tonic clonic;Absence;Typical;Atypical;Myoclonic absence;Eyelid myoclonia;Myoclonic;Myoclonic atonic;Myoclonic tonic;Clonic;Tonic;Atonic;
cdes.permissibleDescription: Tonic clonic (in any combination);Absence;Absence-Typical;Absence-Atypical;Absence-Myoclonic absence;Absence-Eyelid myoclonia;Myoclonic;Myoclonic-Myoclonic atonic;Myoclonic-Myoclonic tonic;Clonic;Tonic;Atonic;
cdes.instructions: Each seizure type needs to be answered using the permissible values for the  Seizure type or subtype present likelihood type  data element.  It is possible for a participant/subject to have more than one seizure type.  Although individual seizure onsets can appear localized, the location and lateralization are not consistent from one seizure to another. Generalized seizures can be asymmetric.
cdes.referrences: EPILEPSY: Berg AT, Berkovic SF, Brodie MJ, Buchhalter J, et al. Revised terminology and concepts for organization of seizures and epilepsies: report of the ILAE Commission on Classification and Terminology, 2005-2009. Epilepsia. 2010 Apr;51(4):676-85. http://www.ilae-epilepsy.org/Visitors/Centre/ctf/ctfoverview.cfm
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Seizure focal classification type
cdes.definitionDescription: The type of focal epileptic seizures, considered to originate within networks limited to one hemisphere, which may be discretely localized or more widely distributed, and may originate in subcortical structures, experience by the participant/subject.
cdes.permissibleValue: Without impairment of consciousness or responsiveness;With observable motor or autonomic components;Involving subjective sensory or psychic phenomena only;With impairment of consciousness or responsiveness;Evolving to a bilateral, convulsive seizure;
cdes.permissibleDescription: Without impairment of consciousness or responsiveness;Without impairment of consciousness or responsiveness-With observable motor or autonomic components (roughly corresponds to the concept of  simple partial seizure );Without impairment of consciousness or responsiveness-Involving subjective sensory or psychic phenomena only (corresponds to the concept of  aura );With impairment of consciousness or responsiveness (roughly corresponds to the concept of  complex partial seizure );Evolving to a bilateral, convulsive seizure (involving tonic, clonic, or tonic and clonic components replaces the term  secondarily generalized seizure );
cdes.instructions: Each seizure type needs to be answered using the permissible values for the  Seizure type or subtype present likelihood type  data element.  It is possible for a participant/subject to have more than one seizure type.  For each seizure type, ictal onset is consistent from one seizure to another with preferential propagation patterns, which can involve the contralateral hemisphere. In some cases, however, there is more than one epileptogenic network, and more than one seizure type, but each individual seizure type has a consistent site of onset. Focal seizures do not fall into any recognized set of natural classes based on any current understanding of the mechanisms involved.
cdes.referrences: EPILEPSY: Berg AT, Berkovic SF, Brodie MJ, Buchhalter J, et al. Revised terminology and concepts for organization of seizures and epilepsies: report of the ILAE Commission on Classification and Terminology, 2005-2009. Epilepsia. 2010 Apr;51(4):676-85. http://www.ilae-epilepsy.org/Visitors/Centre/ctf/ctfoverview.cfm
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Seizure unclassifiable classification type
cdes.definitionDescription: Whether the participant/subject has experienced an unclassifiable seizure that is neither focal or generalized.

cdes.permissibleDescription: Epileptic spasms, focal or generalized;Seizure type is unclassified (If a seizure cannot be adequately classified, it should not be fit into a category to which it does not belong.);

description: Based on the current International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) guidelines, this CRF Module is recommended to classify etiology for all epilepsy studies.

cdes.cdeName: Epilepsy etiology general classification type
cdes.definitionDescription: The categorization for general etiology of epilepsy as linked to either identifed structural or metabolic causes or presumed genetic or unknown causes. Genetic (or presumed) causes of epilepsy are understood to be the direct result of a known or presumed genetic defect(s) in which seizures are the core symptom of the disorder. Unknown cause is meant to be taken neutrally and to designate that the nature of the underlying cause is not yet unknown. Structural or metabolic causes are due to a distinct condition that has been associated with substantially increased risk of developing epilepsy as demonstrated in appropriately designed studies.
cdes.permissibleValue: Genetic or presumed genetic OR epilepsy of unknown cause;Structural or metabolic;
cdes.permissibleDescription: Genetic or presumed genetic OR epilepsy of unknown cause;Structural or metabolic;
cdes.instructions: Choose one. Only one of  Genetic or presumed genetic OR epilepsy of unknown cause  and  Structural or metabolic  should be recorded as present.
cdes.referrences: EPILEPSY: Berg AT, Berkovic SF, Brodie MJ, Buchhalter J, et al. Revised terminology and concepts for organization of seizures and epilepsies: report of the ILAE Commission on Classification and Terminology, 2005-2009. Epilepsia. 2010 Apr;51(4):676-85. http://www.ilae-epilepsy.org/Visitors/Centre/ctf/ctfoverview.cfm
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Epilepsy etiology classification genetic or unknown likelihood type

cdes.cdeName: Epilepsy etiology general attribution confidence type
cdes.definitionDescription: The level of confidence attributed to the categorizing of general etiology of epilepsy to either structural or metabolic causes versus genetic or unknown factors.
cdes.instructions: Choose one. One attribution should be assigned for either  Genetic or presumed genetic OR epilepsy of unknown cause  or  Structural or metabolic , not both.
cdes.referrences: EPILEPSY: Berg AT, Berkovic SF, Brodie MJ, Buchhalter J, et al. Revised terminology and concepts for organization of seizures and epilepsies: report of the ILAE Commission on Classification and Terminology, 2005-2009. Epilepsia. 2010 Apr;51(4):676-85. http://www.ilae-epilepsy.org/Visitors/Centre/ctf/ctfoverview.cfm
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Epilepsy etiology classification structural or metabolic likelihood type

cdes.cdeName: Epilepsy etiology specific classification type
cdes.definitionDescription: The specific etiologies preceeding the development of epilepsy in the participant/subject, as described by the International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE).
cdes.permissibleValue: Viral, bacterial and parasitic infections;Traumatic brain injury;Stroke;Intraventricular hemorrhage;Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy;Other metabolic or toxic insults;Neurocutaneous syndromes;Inborn errors of metabolism;Genetic and chromosomal development encephalopathies;Developmental encephalopathy of unknown cause;Malformations of cortical or other brain development with or without known genetic determinants;Neoplasia;Mesial Temporal Sclerosis;Dementia;Other degenerative neurologic diseases;Genetic or presumed genetic;Epilepsy of unknown cause, without relevant abnormalities on examination, cognition, history, or imaging;Other, specify;
cdes.permissibleDescription: Viral, bacterial and parasitic infections;Traumatic brain injury;Stroke;Intraventricular hemorrhage;Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy;Other metabolic or toxic insults;Neurocutaneous syndromes;Inborn errors of metabolism;Genetic and chromosomal development encephalopathies;Developmental encephalopathy of unknown cause as evidenced by the presence of mental retardation, cerebral palsy, or autism with no evidence of a specific insult or disorder to which cause can be attributed preceding the onset of epilepsy;Malformations of cortical or other brain development with or without known genetic determinants;Neoplasia;Mesial Temporal Sclerosis;Dementia;Other degenerative neurologic diseases;Genetic or presumed genetic;Epilepsy of unknown cause, without relevant abnormalities on examination, cognition, history, or imaging;Other, specify;
cdes.instructions: Specific etiologies are listed, However, where evidence is lacking that a specific etiology proceeds the development of epilepsy, it is not assumed that such pathology causes epilepsy. A response needs to be completed for each etiology - choose one.

description: The physical exam is generally administered at screening and/or baseline to determine study eligibility. It may also be administered at follow-up visits to track a participant's/subject's physical status. This CRF Module captures the physical exam results.

cdes.cdeName: Physical exam date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: Date (and time if applicable and known) physical exam was performed
cdes.instructions: Record the date (and time) the physical exam was performed. Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).

cdes.cdeName: Body system category
cdes.definitionDescription: Category or grouping used in the comprehensive assessment of a participant/subject, which includes a subjective history taking component as well as an objective based structured interview and physical examination of all the body systems.
cdes.permissibleValue: Constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss);Eyes;Ears, Nose, Mouth, Throat;Cardiovascular;Respiratory;Gastrointestinal;Genitourinary;Musculoskeletal;Integumentary (skin and/or breast);Neurological;Psychiatric;Endocrine;Hematologic/Lymphatic;Allergic/Immunologic;
cdes.permissibleDescription: Constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss);Eyes;Ears, Nose, Mouth, Throat;Cardiovascular;Respiratory;Gastrointestinal;Genitourinary;Musculoskeletal;Integumentary (skin and/or breast);Neurological;Psychiatric;Endocrine;Hematologic/Lymphatic;Allergic/Immunologic;
cdes.instructions: Choose one. Response is obtained by report of the participant/subject or proxy as soon as possible after visit/admission. Document the date the history was obtained so it can be determined whether this information was obtained prior to study enrollment or later. Recommend collection at least on date of TBI or at time of first medical treatment.  Comorbidity prior to injury may influence the disease course and chances of recovery. Serious comorbidity or comorbidity that may influence the assessment of outcome are generally considered exclusion criteria in randomized clinical trials. It is therefore highly relevant to accurately record the significant relevant medical history.

cdes.instructions: Answer where applicable  Recommended tests are: Attention-forward digit span (6 is normal for adults), Working Memory-reverse digit span (4 is normal for adults), Recent (Episodic) Memory-immediate recall of 3 objects and then recall again after 3-5 minute delay, Remote (Semantic) Memory-either recall of verifiable personal information from the patient's past (i.e. previous addresses or schools) or well-known current events (i.e. naming the Presidents backwards)

description: This CRF Module captures vital signs, weight, and height. Vital signs can help assess the safety of the intervention and monitor the health of the participants/subjects throughout the study period. Height and weight are commonly collected at the baseline visit.

cdes.cdeName: Vital signs date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: Date (and time, if applicable and known) the vital signs and other body measurements were taken by indicating the month, day, and year for the date and am, pm, or 24 hour clock for time
cdes.instructions: Record the date vital signs are taken. Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Heart rate
cdes.definitionDescription: The participant/subject's pulse or number of contractions (heart beats) per minute
cdes.instructions: Record the pulse of the participant/ subject in beats per minute.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: SCI CDEs: PULSE
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Respiratory rate
cdes.definitionDescription: Rate of the participant/subject's breathing (inhalation and exhalation).
cdes.instructions: Record the respiratory rate of the participant/subject in breaths per minute.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Blood pressure systolic measurement
cdes.definitionDescription: Measurement of pressure of the participant's/subject's blood against the artery walls during systole (the contraction phase) in millimeters of mercury (mmHg)
cdes.instructions: Record the systolic blood pressure of the participant/ subject.  The standard unit for measuring blood pressure is mmHg, which is approximately equivalent to Torr.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: SCI CDEs: BPSYS
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Blood pressure diastolic measurement
cdes.definitionDescription: Measurement of pressure of the participant's/subject's blood against the artery walls during diastole (the relaxation phase) in millimeters of mercury (mmHg)
cdes.instructions: Record the diastolic blood pressure of the participant/ subject.  The standard unit for measuring blood pressure is mmHg, which is approximately equivalent to Torr.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: SCI CDEs: BPDIAS
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Blood pressure measurement position type
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator of the participant/subject's position during the blood pressure measurement.
cdes.instructions: Record the position the participant/ subject was in when the blood pressure was measured.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: caBIG: PART_POS_TP; SCI CDEs: TSTPOSIT
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Temperature measurement
cdes.definitionDescription: Measurement of the participant's/subject's body temperature.
cdes.instructions: Record the temperature of the participant/ subject.  Also indicate the scale used to capture temperature.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: SCI CDEs: TEMPMEAS
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Temperature unit of measure
cdes.definitionDescription: Unit of measure for the temperature numerical value
cdes.instructions: Choose either F (degrees Fahrenheit) or C (degrees Celsius).
cdes.referrences: Unified Code for Units of Measure - http://unitsofmeasure.org/
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Temperature measurement other text
cdes.definitionDescription: The free-text field related to 'Temperature measurement anatomic site' specifying other text. Anatomic site on or within the body where the temperature was measured.
cdes.instructions: Choose one.  Record the location where the temperature was measured.  This elements is most relevant to pediatric clinical studies.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Temperature measurement anatomic site
cdes.definitionDescription: Anatomic site on or within the body where the temperature was measured.
cdes.instructions: Choose one.  Record the location where the temperature was measured.  This elements is most relevant to pediatric clinical studies.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: SCI CDEs: TEMPMETH
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Weight measurement
cdes.definitionDescription: Measurement of participant's/subject's weight
cdes.instructions: Record the weight of the participant/subject. To be collected at the visit, not self-reported. Also, indicate whether weight was measured in pounds (lbs) or kilograms (kg).
cdes.referrences: EPILEPSY: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: SCI CDEs: WEIGHT
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Weight unit of measure
cdes.definitionDescription: Unit of measure for the weight numerical value
cdes.instructions: Choose either Pounds (lb) or Kilograms (kg).
cdes.referrences: Unified Code for Units of Measure - http://unitsofmeasure.org/
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: caBIG: PRSN_WT_UOM_UCUM_CD
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Height measurement
cdes.definitionDescription: Measurement of participant's/subject's height.
cdes.instructions: Record the height (or length for the very young) of the participant/ subject. To be collected at the visit, not self-reported. Also, indicate whether height was measured in inches (in) or centimeters (cm).
cdes.referrences: EPILEPSY: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: SCI CDEs: HEIGHT
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Height unit of measure
cdes.definitionDescription: Unit of measure for the height numerical value for subject/participant
cdes.instructions: Choose either Inches (in) or Centimeters (cm).
cdes.referrences: Unified Code for Units of Measure - http://unitsofmeasure.org/
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Head circumference measurement
cdes.definitionDescription: Circumferential measurement of the head at the widest point - the distance from above the eyebrows and ears and around the back of the head
cdes.instructions: Record the head circumference of the participant/ subject as well as the units for the measurement
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

cdes.cdeName: Head circumference unit of measure
cdes.definitionDescription: Unit of measure for the head circumference numerical value
cdes.instructions: Choose either Inches (in) or Centimeters (cm).
cdes.referrences: Unified Code for Units of Measure - http://unitsofmeasure.org/
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: HEAD_CIRCMF_UNIT_CD
cdes.subDomain: Vital Signs and Other Body Measures

description: This CRF Module provides the minimum requirements for fMRI evaluation in epilepsy.

description: This is an administrative CRF Module and provides the minimum sequences, requirements, and recommendations for co-registration of MEG/ MSI source data.
This CRF Module provides the minimum requirements for PET Localization evaluation in epilepsy. Co-registration with MRI is increasingly performed and may help interpret studies.

cdes.cdeName: Imaging study date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: Date (and time, if applicable and known) the radiologic study was obtained.
cdes.instructions: Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).

cdes.cdeName: EEG posterior dominant rhythm present indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Recorded by electroencephalogram (EEG) over the occipital head region when the individual is relaxed, awake with eyes closed. cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant dose
cdes.definitionDescription: Dose of prior/concomitant medication taken per administration.
cdes.questionText: Total Daily Dose or PRN Dose
cdes.instructions: Record the dose of AED the participant/subject was prescribed to take. Core for all prospective intervention and observation studies. The following abbreviations are recommended to capture dose units: g = gram;gr = grain;gtt = drop;mcg = microgram;mcL = microliter;mg = milligram;mL = milliliter;oz = ounce;SPY = spray/squirt;supp = suppository;TBSP = tablespoon;Sp = teaspoon;OTH = other, specify;UNK= Unknown

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant dose unit of measure
cdes.definitionDescription: Dosage unit of measure of the prior or concomitant medication administered.
cdes.instructions: Record the unit for dose of AED the participant/subject was prescribed to take. Core for all prospective intervention and observacation studies. Examples of dose units include: g = gram; gr = grain; gtt = drop; mcg = microgram; mcL = microliter; mg = milligram; mL = milliliter; oz = ounce; SPY = spray/squirt; supp = suppository; TBSP = Tablespoon; tsp = teaspoon; OTH = other, specify; UNK = unknown
cdes.referrences: Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM) - http://unitsofmeasure.org/

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant start date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: The date (and time, if applicable and known) on which the prior/concomitant medication usage began.
cdes.instructions: Record the date (and time) the participant/subject started taking the medication. Start Date can be used to distinguish between prior medications and concomitant medications.  Core for all prospective intervention and observation studies. Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant start date and time

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant end date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: The date (and time, if applicable and known) the administration of the prior/concomitant medication ended.
cdes.instructions:
Record the date (and time) the participant/subject stopped taking the medication. The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.) and in the format acceptable to the study database. Stop Date should be recorded if Ongoing Medication is answered No. Conversely, Stop Date should remain blank if Ongoing Medication is answered Yes.
Core for all prospective intervention  and observation studies
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant end date and time

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant ongoing indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator of or description that the prior/concomitant medication usage is ongoing.
cdes.instructions:
Choose one. Answer YES if the participant/subject is still taking the medication or NO if the participant/subject has stopped taking the medication.
Core for all prospective intervention  and observation studies
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant ongoing indicator

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant indication text
cdes.definitionDescription: Text describing reason for administration of a prior/concomitant (nonstudy) agent or measure. This is not the pharmacologic classification of an agent (antibiotic, analgesic, etc.), but the reason for its administration to the participant/subject.
cdes.instructions: Record the reason the participant/subject gives for taking the medication. If given for an Adverse Event (AE), enter exact term from Adverse Event CRF. The indication for the AED medication should be recorded in the database as  epileptic seizure control  to distinguish the AEDs from other prior or concomitant medications taken during the study.  The indication does NOT need to be recorded on the CRF. Core for all prospective intervention and observation studies
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant indication text

description: This CRF Module is recommended for studies that involve surgery, as it collects surgical details, post-operative course information, and pathology data.

cdes.cdeName: Surgical or therapeutic procedure start date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: Date (and time, if applicable and known) on which the surgical or therapeutic procedure started
cdes.instructions: Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Refer to SCI CDE Annotated Form

crfModuleGuideline: Overview of Recommended Adverse Event Reporting Instruments
description: Provides a summary of the recommended adverse event reporting instruments, specifically for persons with epilepsy.

These recommendations contain a survey of the available Anti Epileptic Drug (AED) Adverse Event collection tools. The tools should be considered as supplemental, as the primary tool for a prospective study should be spontaneous report, using the Adverse Event Tracking Log CRF Module.

This CRF Module is the epilepsy-specific version of the General Adverse Event (AE) CRF Module. It contains additional elements relevant to epilepsy research, including action taken with study drug/ device, and action taken with Anti Epileptic Drug (AED).

cdes.cdeName: Unexpected adverse event indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator of whether the adverse event is unexpected
cdes.instructions: Choose Yes or No.  This question should be answered YES if the AE was not previously identified as an adverse event associated with use of the investigational drug or medical device, based on those described in the Investigator’s Brochure.  An event may also be identified as unexpected if the adverse event increased in frequency or severity than what is described by the Investigator’s Brochure.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event during study indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator of whether the participant/subject experienced any adverse events during the study
cdes.questionText: Has the participant/subject had any adverse events during the study?
cdes.instructions: Choose one. If answered Yes, at least one AE must be recorded.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: AE_YN

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event verbatim term text
cdes.definitionDescription: Text that describes the adverse event word for word as described by the participant/subject
cdes.instructions: Any untoward medical occurrence in a study participant/subject that does not necessarily have a causal relationship with the study intervention. An AE can therefore be any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a study intervention or study procedure, whether or not related to the study intervention or procedure. Each AE should be listed on a separate line. Any worsening of a baseline condition or reoccurrence of a baseline condition that had previously ended for a time should be listed as an AE. Events, such as nausea and vomiting are considered two events, and therefore should be listed on separate lines. A participant/subject may experience an unexpected AE. An unexpected adverse reaction has a nature or severity of which is not consistent with the study intervention description (e.g. Investigator's Brochure for an unapproved investigational product or package insert/summary of product characteristics for an approved product). The unexpected AE must be reported, whether related to the study intervention or not, with as much detail as is available.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: AE_VERBATIM_TRM_TXT

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event CTCAE low level term name
cdes.definitionDescription: Text that represents the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) low level term name for an adverse event.
cdes.instructions: Code the adverse event verbatim text with the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) low level term name.  CTCAE is a freely available standard terminology for adverse event data.
cdes.referrences: Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) v4.0 (http://evs.nci.nih.gov/ftp1/CTCAE/About.html)
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: CTCAE4_LLT_NM
cdes.previousTitle: Adverse event CTCAE low level term name

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event MedDRA lower level term code
cdes.definitionDescription: Code that corresponds to the Medical Dictionary for Regulatory Activities (MedDRA) Lower Level Term (LLT) for an adverse event
cdes.instructions: Code the adverse event verbatim text with the Medical Dictionary for Regulatory Activities (MedDRA) Lower Level Term (LLT) codes.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: CTCAE4_M_LLTMEDDRACD
cdes.previousTitle: Adverse event MedDRA lower level term code

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event start date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: Date (and time, if applicable and known) on which the adverse event was first evident
cdes.instructions: Record the date (and time) the adverse event started. If a previously recorded AE worsens, a new record should be created with a new start date. There should be no AE start date prior to the date of the informed consent. Any AE that started prior to the informed consent date belongs instead in the medical history. If an item recorded on the medical history worsens during the study, the date of the worsening is entered as an AE with the start date as the date the condition worsened. Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: AE_ONSET_DT
cdes.previousTitle: Adverse event start date and time

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event end date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: Date (and time, if applicable and known) on which the adverse event discontinued/stopped
cdes.instructions: Record the date (and time) the adverse event stopped or worsened.  If an AE worsens, record an end date and create a new AE record with a new start date and severity. Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: AE_RESOLV_ALDT
cdes.previousTitle: Adverse event end date and time

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event severity grade scale
cdes.definitionDescription: The grading scale of the severity or intensity of the adverse event
cdes.permissibleDescription: Mild: asymptomatic or mild symtoms, clinical or diagnostic observations only, intervention not indicated.;Moderate: minimal, local or noninvasive intervention indicated, limiting age-appropriate Activities of Daily Living.;Severe or medically significant but not immediately life-threatening: hospitalization or prolongation of hospitalization indicated, disabling, limiting self care Activities of Daily Living;Life-threatening consequences: urgent intervention indicated;Death related to adverse event;
cdes.instructions: Choose the one severity that best describes the investigator's assessment of the intensity of the AE. The five severity grades are from the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events v4.0 (CTCAE). Severe events interrupt the participant's/subject's normal daily activities and generally require systemic drug therapy or other treatment; they are usually incapacitating. Consequently, a change in severity may constitute a new reportable AE. Severity is not synonymous with seriousness. A severe rash is not likely to be an SAE. Likewise, a severe headache is not necessarily an SAE. However, mild chest pain may result in a day's hospitalization and thus is an SAE. It is helpful to define the severity categories in the protocol or Manual of Operations to obtain consistency in reporting across sites.
cdes.referrences: Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) v4.0 (http://evs.nci.nih.gov/ftp1/CTCAE/About.html)
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: CTC_AE_REP_GD

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event relatedness scale
cdes.definitionDescription: Scale of the causality between the treatment modality/intervention and the specific adverse event
cdes.instructions: Choose one. Record the investigator’s assessment as to whether there is at least a reasonable possibility that the AE is related to (or caused by) use of the study intervention.  Definitions for each of the relatedness responses should be supplied in the protocol.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: CTC_AE_ATTR_SCALE

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event study intervention action taken type
cdes.definitionDescription: Type of action taken for adverse event in relation to study intervention
cdes.permissibleValue: None;Study Intervention Interrupted;Study Intervention Discontinued;Study Intervention Modified;
cdes.permissibleDescription: None;Study Intervention Interrupted;Study Intervention Discontinued;Study Intervention Modified;
cdes.instructions: Choose one. If treatment was required, then the corresponding treatment needs to be recorded on the Prior and Concomitant Medications CRF.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: AE_ACT_STDY_INTRVN
cdes.previousTitle: Adverse event study intervention action taken type

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event AED action taken text
cdes.definitionDescription: Text of action taken with the anti-epileptic drug (AED) due to the adverse event
cdes.instructions: Choose one.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Adverse event AED action taken type

cdes.cdeName: Adverse event outcome status
cdes.definitionDescription: Final status of the participant/subject related to the adverse event
cdes.instructions: Choose one outcome. The outcome of an AE may not be captured at the visit during which it was first reported, but must eventually be captured to provide a complete picture of the event. Entering the outcome of an AE may be deferred until the AE is resolved, or the participant/subject completes the study. For AEs that have not resolved at the time of a study visit, the outcome should be marked as  Not recovered/not resolved  on the AE case report form.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: AE_OUTCOME_TXT_TP

cdes.cdeName: Serious adverse event indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator of whether the adverse event is serious.
cdes.instructions: Choose either Yes or No. This question should only be answered YES if the outcome of the AE results in at least one of the following: death; a life-threatening adverse drug experience; results in inpatient hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization; a persistent or significant disability/incapacity; or a congenital anomaly/birth defect. If an AE is serious, this provides a trigger that additional information must be provided by the site investigator. The site investigator then completes a Serious Adverse Event (SAE) form. Additionally, the site institution and/or IRB may also have an SAE form and procedures for reporting SAEs.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: AE_SERIOUS_IND

description: The Side Effects Scale (Hague) assess possible side-effects of medications for epilepsy, to be completed by a parent/guardian.

cdes.cdeName: Hague Side Effects Scale (HASES) - drowsiness sleepiness scale
cdes.definitionDescription: The reported level of severity of drowsiness and sleepiness noticed by a guardian following administration of antiepileptic medication in a participant/subject during the past 3 months according to Hague Side Effects Scale (HASES).
cdes.instructions: Have you noticed any of the following side-effects of antiepileptic medication in your child during the past 3 months?

description: The VA Toxicity Scale Consists of two sections which focus on neurotoxicity.

cdes.cdeName: Veterans Affairs Toxicity Scale - drug-related gastrointenstinal problem indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicate whether the patient has any drug-related gastrointestinal problems.
cdes.questionText: Does the patient have any drug-related gastrointestinal problems?
cdes.instructions: All toxicity is scored relative to normal for the participant/subject before starting medication
cdes.referrences: Cramer J et al. A method of quantification for the evaluation of antiepileptic drug therapy. Neurology. 1983; 33[Suppl] 11: 26-37.  Contact: joyce.cramer@yale.edu
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: VA Toxicity Scale  part A Q1

cdes.cdeName: Veterans Affairs Toxicity Scale - gastrointenstinal problem transient or occassionally score
cdes.definitionDescription: Circle the pre-specified scores for gastrointestional symptoms (distress, nausea, vomitting) if these symptoms occur transiently or occassionally after medication.
cdes.permissibleDescription: Transient occasional distress;Transient occasional nausea;Transient occasional vomiting;
cdes.instructions: For gastrointestinal problems (distress, nausea, vomiting), circle the highest applicable score for participant/subject symptoms and enter it in the appropriate score box. Enter zero on the other two score lines.
cdes.referrences: Cramer J et al. A method of quantification for the evaluation of antiepileptic drug therapy. Neurology. 1983; 33[Suppl] 11: 26-37.  Contact: joyce.cramer@yale.edu
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.instructions: For gastrointestinal problems (distress, nausea, vomiting), circle the highest applicable score for participant/subject symptoms and enter it in the appropriate score box. Enter zero on the other two score lines.
cdes.referrences: Cramer J et al. A method of quantification for the evaluation of antiepileptic drug therapy. Neurology. 1983; 33[Suppl] 11: 26-37.  Contact: joyce.cramer@yale.edu
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.definitionDescription: Circle the pre-specified scores for gastrointestional symptoms (distress, nausea, vomitting) if these symptoms occur often and during the day after medication
cdes.permissibleDescription: Often during the day distress;Often during the day nausea;Often during the day vomiting;
cdes.instructions: For gastrointestinal problems (distress, nausea, vomiting), circle the highest applicable score for participant/subject symptoms and enter it in the appropriate score box. Enter zero on the other two score lines.

cdes.definitionDescription: The free-text field to specify drug-related gastrointestinal problems other than distress, nausea or vomiting as part of the Veterans Affairs (VA) Toxicity Scale.
cdes.questionText: specify drug-related gastrointestional problems other than distress, nausea or vomiting in text
cdes.instructions: Answer for Q1a - Q1c, as applicable; Specify other drug-related gastrointestinal problems if applicable.
cdes.referrences: Cramer J et al. A method of quantification for the evaluation of antiepileptic drug therapy. Neurology. 1983; 33[Suppl] 11: 26-37.  Contact: joyce.cramer@yale.edu

cdes.cdeName: Veterans Affairs Toxicity Scale - hematopoietic system problems indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicate whether or not the patient has any drug-related hematopoietic system problems
cdes.questionText: Does the patient have hematopoietic system problems?
cdes.instructions: If yes, proceed to 2a.  If no, skip to part A Q3. If yes, enter a score for each the following (enter zero if not present).
cdes.referrences: Cramer J et al. A method of quantification for the evaluation of antiepileptic drug therapy. Neurology. 1983; 33[Suppl] 11: 26-37.  Contact: joyce.cramer@yale.edu
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: VA Toxicity Scale  part A Q2

cdes.cdeName: Veterans Affairs Toxicity Scale - reduced platelet count score
cdes.definitionDescription: Pre-specified scores for the reduced platelet count <75,000 (seen on more than 1 test) under two situations: drug under observation or drug discontinued. If not present, enter zero for the score
cdes.questionText: circle and enter the higher score that applies to your reduced platelet count <75,000 (seen on more than 1 test): drug under observation or drug discontinued.
cdes.instructions: Record a score. If not present, record as zero. Circle one  score only if  yes  to  reduced WBC . Enter the higher score that applies under column  Score .
cdes.referrences: Cramer J et al. A method of quantification for the evaluation of antiepileptic drug therapy. Neurology. 1983; 33[Suppl] 11: 26-37.  Contact: joyce.cramer@yale.edu
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: VA Toxicity Scale  part A Q2a

cdes.cdeName: Veterans Affairs Toxicity Scale - reduced WBC count score
cdes.definitionDescription: Pre-specified scores for the reduced WBC <2,000 (1000 granulacytes) (seen on more than 1 test) or discontinued drug
cdes.questionText: circle and enter the higher score that applies to your reduced WBC <2,000 (1000 granulacytes) (seen on more than 1 test): drug under observation or drug discontinued.
cdes.instructions: Record a score. If not present, record as zero. Circle one  score only if  yes  to  reduced WBC . Enter the higher score that applies under column  Score .
cdes.referrences: Cramer J et al. A method of quantification for the evaluation of antiepileptic drug therapy. Neurology. 1983; 33[Suppl] 11: 26-37.  Contact: joyce.cramer@yale.edu
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.referrences: Cramer J et al. A method of quantification for the evaluation of antiepileptic drug therapy. Neurology. 1983; 33[Suppl] 11: 26-37.  Contact: joyce.cramer@yale.edu
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: VA Toxicity Scale  part A Q2c

cdes.cdeName: Veterans Affairs Toxicity Scale - hematopoietic problems total score
cdes.definitionDescription: Summation of the circled scores for hematopoietic system problems on the Veterans Affairs Toxicity Scale.
cdes.questionText: Sum the circled scores for hemotopoietic system problems and enter the total score
cdes.instructions: Record the total score as the summation of Q2a - Q2c
cdes.referrences: Cramer J et al. A method of quantification for the evaluation of antiepileptic drug therapy. Neurology. 1983; 33[Suppl] 11: 26-37.  Contact: joyce.cramer@yale.edu
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Veterans Affairs Toxicity Scale - hematopoietic problems other score
cdes.definitionDescription: Score hematopoietic problem other than reduced platelets and WBC problems, if applicable
cdes.instructions: Enter a score only if other hematopoietic problem is described. Instructions for each of the CDEs is included on the CRF F1128, or see Cramer et al (1983).

cdes.questionText: If the patient has gained or lost weight, select the score for one of the following that applies: Small (4-6 lbs); Moderate (7-12 lbs); Large (13-18 lbs)
cdes.instructions: Record score for both weight gain and weight loss, if applicable. Circle one of the three scores only if  yes  to the question  Has patient gained or lost weight?  and enter under column  Score
cdes.referrences: Cramer J et al. A method of quantification for the evaluation of antiepileptic drug therapy. Neurology. 1983; 33[Suppl] 11: 26-37.  Contact: joyce.cramer@yale.edu

cdes.cdeName: Veterans Affairs Toxicity Scale - weight change score

cdes.instructions: Enter the applicable score under column  Score  only if   yes  to the question  Has patient gained or lost weight?   Record the total score as the summation of Q7a - Q7b

crfModuleGuideline: Overview of Instruments for Assessing Comorbidities
description: Summarizes the instruments recommended to assess conditions/ disorders that are common comorbidities for persons with epilepsy. Three types of instruments are listed: Psychiatric, Cognitive, and those for assessing Migraines.

Recommends instruments for those epilepsy studies that intend to screen for cognitive status. The recommendations are broken down by primary and secondary areas of cognitive function. If a more thorough assessment of cognition is a goal of the study, the Recommended Neuropsychology Instruments should be consulted.

Recommends instruments for epilepsy studies that intend to screen for, or study, frequently occurring psychiatric disorders. The recommendations are broken down by psychiatric areas/ domains of interest. The primary area of importance is depression; with secondary areas including anxiety, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), autism, posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), psychosis, and survey of DSM-IV Axis I disorders.
These recommendations contain a survey of the available instruments for assessing the comorbidity of convulsive disorders with migraine, in both adults and pediatrics.
The ASRS is a self-report scale for adults to help in evaluating adults with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

cdes.cdeName: Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS) - wrapping up frequency
cdes.definitionDescription: The frequency assessment for trouble wrapping up final details in the Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS) Symptom Checklist, a self-reported questionnaire used to assist in the diagnosis of adult ADHD.
cdes.questionText: How often do you have trouble wrapping up the final details of a project, once the challenging parts have been done?
cdes.instructions: Check the box that best describes how you have felt and conducted  yourself over the past 6 months.
cdes.referrences: Kessler RC, Adler L, Ames M, Demler O, Faraone S, Hiripi E, Howes MJ, Jin R, Secnik K, Spencer T, Ustun TB, Walters EE. The World Health Organization Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS). 2005. Psychological Medicine. 2005; 35(2): 245-56.

cdes.cdeName: Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS) - total score
cdes.definitionDescription: The total score related to the Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS) Symptom Checklist, a self-reported questionnaire used to assist in the diagnosis of adult ADHD.
cdes.questionText: Add the number of checkmarks that appear in the darkly shaded area.
cdes.instructions: Add the number of checkmarks that appear in the darkly shaded area. Four (4) or more checkmarks indicate that your symptoms may be consistent with adult ADHD. It may be beneficial for you to talk with your healthcare provider about an evaluation.

description: The purpose of the AmNART is to characterize level of general cognitive function and provide a frame of reference from which to interpret other performances, particularly those that are language related.

description: The purpose of the CHAT is to identify toddlers 18-months of age who are at risk for autism.

cdes.cdeName: Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) - enjoy knee bounce indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator if child enjoys being swung, bounced on your knee.  This is from the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) which is a screening instrument which identifies children aged 18 months who are at risk of having social-communication disorders.
cdes.instructions: To completed by the parent
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.

cdes.instructions: To completed by the parent
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator if child pretend, for example, to make a cup of tea using a toy cup and teapot, or pretend other things. cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.instructions: To completed by the parent
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator if child ever uses his/her index finger to point, to indicate interest in something.  This is from the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) which is a screening instrument which identifies children aged 18 months who are at risk of having social-communication disorders.

cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator if child plays properly with small toys (e.g. cars or bricks) without just mouthing, fiddling or dropping them.  This is from the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) which is a screening instrument which identifies children aged 18 months who are at risk of having social-communication disorders.
cdes.instructions: To completed by the parent
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) - bring objects over show indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator if child ever brings objects over to parent to show something.  This is from the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) which is a screening instrument which identifies children aged 18 months who are at risk of having social-communication disorders.
cdes.instructions: To completed by the parent
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.

cdes.cdeName: Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) - eye contact indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator if child, during the appointment, has the child made eye contact.  This is from the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) which is a screening instrument which identifies children aged 18 months who are at risk of having social-communication disorders.
cdes.questionText: During the appointment, has the child made eye contact with you?
cdes.instructions: General practitioner's (GP) or Health Visitor's observation
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) - look pointing indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator if child gets easily distracted as outlined in the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) which is a screening instrument which identifies children aged 18 months who are at risk of having social-communication disorders.
cdes.questionText: Get child's attention, then point across the room at an interesting object and say  Oh look! There’s a (name of toy)!  Watch child’s face. Does the child look across to see what you are pointing at?
cdes.instructions: General practitioner's (GP) or Health Visitor's observation.  To record Yes on this item, ensure the child has not simply looked at your hand, but has actually looked at the object you are pointing at.
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) - pretend tea drink indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator if child enjoys being swung, bounced on your knee from the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) which is a screening instrument which identifies children aged 18 months who are at risk of having social-communication disorders.
cdes.questionText: Get the child's attention, then give child a miniature toy cup and teapot and say  Can you make a cup of tea?  Does the child pretend to pour out tea, drink it, etc.?
cdes.instructions: General practitioner's (GP) or Health Visitor's observation.  If you can elicit an example of pretending in some other game, score a Yes on this item.
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) - point index finger light indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator if child uses index finger to point at light as directed.  This is from the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) which is a screening instrument which identifies children aged 18 months who are at risk of having social-communication disorders.
cdes.questionText: Say to the child  Where’s the light?  or  Show me the light.  Does the child POINT with his/her index finger at the light?
cdes.instructions: General practitioner's (GP) or Health Visitor's observation.  Repeat this with  Where's the teddy?  or some other unreachable object, if child does not understand the word  light . To record Yes on this item, the child must have looked up at your face around the time of pointing.
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) - build tower bricks indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator if child can build a tower of bricks.  This is from the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) which is a screening instrument to identify children aged 18 months who are at risk of having social-communication disorders.
cdes.questionText: Can the child build a tower of bricks?
cdes.instructions: General practitioner's (GP) or Health Visitor's observation.  If so how many?
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) - bricks count
cdes.definitionDescription: The number of bricks that child can use to build a tower as specified from the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT) which is a screening instrument to identify children aged 18 months who are at risk of having social-communication disorders.
cdes.instructions: General practitioner's (GP) or Health Visitor's observation.
cdes.referrences: Baron-Cohen S, Wheelwrigh S, Cox A, et al. The early identification of autism: the Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (CHAT). Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2000; 93: 521-525.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Headache Screening Survey (HSS) - household member headache symptom type
cdes.definitionDescription: The types of headache symptoms experience by each members of a participant's household who suffer from severe headaches from Headache Screening Survey (HSS) which is a questionnaire that screens for alcohol dependency without it appearing to be the main focus of the instrument.
cdes.questionText: When you have a severe headache, do you experience any of the following?
cdes.permissibleValue: Nausea;Vomiting;Pain on one side of head only;Pulsating/throbbing headaches;Pain-free intervals of days or weeks between severe headache attacks;Sensitivity to light;Sensitivity to noise;Blurring of vision;Seeing shimmering lights, circles, other shapes, or colors before the eyes, before the headache starts;Numbness of lips, tongue, fingers, or legs before the headache starts;
cdes.permissibleDescription: Nausea;Vomiting;Pain on one side of head only;Pulsating/throbbing headaches;Pain-free intervals of days or weeks between severe headache attacks;Sensitivity to light;Sensitivity to noise;Blurring of vision;Seeing shimmering lights, circles, other shapes, or colors before the eyes, before the headache starts;Numbness of lips, tongue, fingers, or legs before the headache starts;
cdes.instructions: Choose all that apply. Completed by and answered for each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.

cdes.cdeName: Headache Screening Survey (HSS) - severe headache previous medication indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator for having taken prescription medication for headache on a daily basis from Headache Screening Survey (HSS) which is a questionnaire that screens for alcohol dependency without it appearing to be the main focus of the instrument.
cdes.questionText: Have you ever taken prescription medication for headache on a DAILY basis, whether or not you have a headache, to help prevent a severe headache from happening in the first place?
cdes.instructions: Completed by each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.
cdes.referrences: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Headache Screening Survey (HSS) - other current daily medication type

cdes.permissibleValue: Water pill or prescription diuretic| or high blood pressure;Prescription medicine (other than water pill) for high blood pressure;Prescription medicine for seizures, epilepsy or fits;Prescription medicine for diabetes;Prescription medicine for cholesterol;Prescription medicine for depression or anxiety;

cdes.instructions: Completed by each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.

cdes.cdeName: Headache Screening Survey (HSS) - migraine diagnosis age value
cdes.definitionDescription: The age value of being diagnosed with migraines from Headache Screening Survey (HSS) which is a questionnaire that screens for alcohol dependency without it appearing to be the main focus of the instrument.

cdes.instructions: Write in age.  Completed by each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.

cdes.cdeName: Headache Screening Survey (HSS) - migraine household total count
cdes.definitionDescription: How many household members (including yourself) suffer from MIGRAINE headaches?
cdes.questionText: How many household members (including yourself) suffer from MIGRAINE headaches? number who suffer migrain headaches:
cdes.instructions: Write in number.
cdes.referrences: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Headache Screening Survey (HSS) - household member headache occurrence year frequency
cdes.definitionDescription: The number headaches experienced by each members of a participant's household who suffer from severe headaches in a year from Headache Screening Survey (HSS) which is a questionnaire that screens for alcohol dependency without it appearing to be the main focus of the instrument.
cdes.questionText: About how often do your severe headaches occur? number in a year
cdes.instructions: Answer for headache days per week OR per month OR in a year. Completed by and answered for each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.
cdes.referrences: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Headache Screening Survey (HSS) - no household work day count
cdes.definitionDescription: The number of days in the last 3 months that person could not do household work because of  headaches from Headache Screening Survey (HSS) which is a questionnaire that screens for alcohol dependency without it appearing to be the main focus of the instrument.
cdes.questionText: Because of your headaches on how many days in the last 3 months did you not do household work?
cdes.instructions: Write in number of days.  Completed by each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.
cdes.referrences: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Headache Screening Survey (HSS) - reduced household work day count
cdes.definitionDescription: The number of days in the last 3 months that productivity in household work was reduced by half or more because of headaches from Headache Screening Survey (HSS) which is a questionnaire that screens for alcohol dependency without it appearing to be the main focus of the instrument.
cdes.questionText: Because of your headaches on how many days in the last 3 months was your productivity in household work reduced by half or more?
cdes.instructions: Write in number of days. Do not include days counted in question 10c. Completed by each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.
cdes.referrences: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Headache Screening Survey (HSS) - missed activity day count
cdes.definitionDescription: The number of days in the last 3 months person missed family, social or leisure activities because of headaches from Headache Screening Survey (HSS) which is a questionnaire that screens for alcohol dependency without it appearing to be the main focus of the instrument.
cdes.questionText: Because of your headaches on how many days in the last 3 months did you miss family, social or leisure activities?
cdes.instructions: Write in number of days.  Completed by each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.
cdes.referrences: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Height measurement
cdes.definitionDescription: Measurement of participant's/subject's height.
cdes.instructions: Record the height (or length for the very young) of the participant/subject. To be collected at the visit, not self-reported. Also, indicate whether height was measured in inches (in) or centimeters (cm). Completed by each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.
cdes.referrences: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: SCI CDEs: HEIGHT

cdes.cdeName: Height unit of measure
cdes.definitionDescription: Unit of measure for the height numerical value for subject/participant
cdes.instructions: Choose either Inches (in) or Centimeters (cm). Completed by each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.
cdes.referrences: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Weight measurement
cdes.definitionDescription: Measurement of participant's/subject's weight
cdes.instructions: Record the weight of the participant/subject. To be collected at the visit, not self-reported. Also, indicate whether weight was measured in pounds (lbs) or kilograms (kg). Completed by each member of your household who suffers from severe headaches.
cdes.referrences: Lipton RL, et al. Prevalence and burden of Migraine in the United States: Data from the American Migraine Study II. Headache. 2001; 41: 646-657.

cdes.permissibleDescription: Weekly status ratings prior to the introductions of a new diagnosis should be coded  0 ;Previously was full criteria DSM-IV for this disorder, but currently there is no evidence of the disorder;Previously was full criteria DSM-IV for this disorder and now has only enough symptoms to remain in the episode at less than full criteria;Currently meets full criteria DSM-IV for this disorder;
cdes.instructions: Code the PSR score for each week
cdes.referrences: Keller MB, Lavori PW, Friedman B, Nielsen E, Endicott J, McDonald-Scott P, Andreason NC. The Longitudinal Interval Follow-up Evaluation: A comprehensive method for assessing outcome in prospective longitudinal studies. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 1987; 44: 540-548.   Warshaw MG, Dyck I, Allsworth J, Stout RL, Keller MB. Maintaining reliability in a long-term psychiatric study: an ongoing inter-rater reliability monitoring program using the longitudinal interval follow-up evaluation. J Psychiatr Res. 2001; 35(5): 297-305.

cdes.cdeName: Longitudinal Interval Follow-Up Evaluation (LIFE) - death date
cdes.definitionDescription: Date of subject's death as captured by the Longitudinal Interval Follow-Up Evaluation (LIFE)
cdes.instructions: Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).

description: The GAD-7 is an anxiety scale that can be used for assessing anxiety severity in clinical practices and in research.

description: Conner's Continuous Performance Test III

crfModuleGuideline: Controlled Oral Word Association Test (COWAT) subtest of the Multilingual Aphasia Examination (MAE)
description: Controlled Oral Word Association Test (COWAT) subtest of the Multilingual Aphasia Examination (MAE)

The BDI-II was developed in 1996 and was derived from the BDI. The 21-item survey is self-administered and is scored on a scale of 0-3 in a list of four statements arranged in increasing severity about a particular symptom of depression, bringing the BDI-II into alignment with DSM-IV criteria.

cdes.cdeName: Beck Depression Inventory II (BDI-II) - Sadness scale
cdes.definitionDescription: Scale identifying level of sadness, as part of the Beck Depression Inventory II (BDI-II).
cdes.permissibleDescription: I do not feel sad;I feel sad much of the time;I am sad all the time;I am so sad or unhappy that I can't stand it;
cdes.instructions: Please read each group of statements carefully, and then pick out the one statement in each group that best describes the way you have been feeling the past two weeks, including today. Circle the number beside the statement you have picked. If several statements in the group seem to apply equally well, circle the highest number for that group. Be sure you do not choose more than one statement for any group.
cdes.referrences: Beck AT, Steer RA, Brown GK. Manual for The Beck Depression Inventory Second Edition (BDI-II). San Antonio: Psychological Corporation; 1996.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

description: The Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) has been widely used in PD psychiatric clinical trials and is the easiest/shortest to administer. It was initially developed for schizophrenia. The instrument should be used in cognitively intact subjects and does not require an informant.
